segment.source: Packaged apps and packaged app installer rules in AppLocker (Windows 10)
segment.target: Packaged apps and packaged app installer rules in AppLocker (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic explains the AppLocker rule collection for packaged app installers and packaged apps.
segment.target: This topic explains the AppLocker rule collection for packaged app installers and packaged apps.

segment.source: Packaged apps and packaged app installer rules in AppLocker
segment.target: Packaged apps and packaged app installer rules in AppLocker

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic explains the AppLocker rule collection for packaged app installers and packaged apps.
segment.target: This topic explains the AppLocker rule collection for packaged app installers and packaged apps.

segment.source: Universal Windows apps can be installed through the Windows Store or can be sideloaded using the Windows PowerShell cmdlets.
segment.target: Universal Windows apps can be installed through the Windows Store or can be sideloaded using the Windows PowerShell cmdlets.

segment.source: Universal Windows apps can be installed by a standard user unlike some Classic Windows applications that sometimes require administrative privileges for installation.
segment.target: Universal Windows apps can be installed by a standard user unlike some Classic Windows applications that sometimes require administrative privileges for installation.

segment.source: Typically, an app consists of multiple components – the installer used to install the app and one or more exes, dlls or scripts.
segment.target: Typically, an app consists of multiple components – the installer used to install the app and one or more exes, dlls or scripts.

segment.source: With Classic Windows applications, not all those components always share common attributes such as the publisher name, product name and product version.
segment.target: With Classic Windows applications, not all those components always share common attributes such as the publisher name, product name and product version.

segment.source: Therefore, AppLocker has to control each of these components separately through different rule collections – exe, dll, script and Windows Installers.
segment.target: Therefore, AppLocker has to control each of these components separately through different rule collections – exe, dll, script and Windows Installers.

segment.source: In contrast, all the components of a Universal Windows app share the same attributes: Publisher name, Package name and Package version.
segment.target: In contrast, all the components of a Universal Windows app share the same attributes: Publisher name, Package name and Package version.

segment.source: It is therefore possible to control an entire app with a single rule.
segment.target: It is therefore possible to control an entire app with a single rule.

segment.source: AppLocker enforces rules for Universal Windows apps separately from Classic Windows applications.
segment.target: AppLocker enforces rules for Universal Windows apps separately from Classic Windows applications.

segment.source: A single AppLocker rule for a Universal Windows app can control both the installation and the running of an app.
segment.target: A single AppLocker rule for a Universal Windows app can control both the installation and the running of an app.

segment.source: Because all Universal Windows apps are signed, AppLocker supports only publisher rules for Universal Windows apps.
segment.target: Because all Universal Windows apps are signed, AppLocker supports only publisher rules for Universal Windows apps.

segment.source: A publisher rule for a Universal Windows app is based on the following attributes of the app:
segment.target: A publisher rule for a Universal Windows app is based on the following attributes of the app:

segment.source: Publisher name
segment.target: Publisher name

segment.source: Package name
segment.target: Package name

segment.source: Package version
segment.target: Package version

segment.source: In summary, including AppLocker rules for Universal Windows apps in your policy design provides:
segment.target: In summary, including AppLocker rules for Universal Windows apps in your policy design provides:

segment.source: The ability to control the installation and running of the app
segment.target: The ability to control the installation and running of the app

segment.source: The ability to control all the components of the app with a single rule rather than controlling individual binaries within the app
segment.target: The ability to control all the components of the app with a single rule rather than controlling individual binaries within the app

segment.source: The ability to create application control policies that survive app updates
segment.target: The ability to create application control policies that survive app updates

segment.source: Management of Universal Windows apps through Group Policy.
segment.target: Management of Universal Windows apps through Group Policy.
